trans-unit.source: This level of protection may or may not be adequate for you, but it is more secure than the previous examples.

seg-source.mrk: This level of protection may or may not be adequate for you, but it is more secure than the previous examples.

target.mrk: This level of protection may or may not be adequate for you, but it is more secure than the previous examples.

trans-unit.source: The command line appears on multiple lines to improve readability, but you would enter it as a single <codeph>java</codeph> command.

seg-source.mrk: The command line appears on multiple lines to improve readability, but you would enter it as a single <codeph>java</codeph> command.

target.mrk: The command line appears on multiple lines to improve readability, but you would enter it as a single <codeph>java</codeph> command.

trans-unit.source: java -Dcom.sun.management.jmxremote.port=9999 -Dcom.sun.management.jmxremote.password.file=jmxremote.password -Djavax.net.ssl.keyStore=/home/user/.keystore -Djavax.net.ssl.keyStorePassword=myKeyStorePassword -Dcom.sun.management.jmxremote.ssl.need.client.auth=true -Djavax.net.ssl.trustStore=/home/user/.truststore -Djavax.net.ssl.trustStorePassword=myTrustStorePassword -Dcom.sun.management.jmxremote.registry.ssl=true -Djava.security.manager -Djava.security.policy=jmx.policy -jar lib/derbyrun.jar server start -h 0.0.0.0

seg-source.mrk: java -Dcom.sun.management.jmxremote.port=9999 -Dcom.sun.management.jmxremote.password.file=jmxremote.password -Djavax.net.ssl.keyStore=/home/user/.keystore -Djavax.net.ssl.keyStorePassword=myKeyStorePassword -Dcom.sun.management.jmxremote.ssl.need.client.auth=true -Djavax.net.ssl.trustStore=/home/user/.truststore -Djavax.net.ssl.trustStorePassword=myTrustStorePassword -Dcom.sun.management.jmxremote.registry.ssl=true -Djava.security.manager -Djava.security.policy=jmx.policy -jar lib/derbyrun.jar server start -h 0.0.0.0

target.mrk: java -Dcom.sun.management.jmxremote.port=9999 -Dcom.sun.management.jmxremote.password.file=jmxremote.password -Djavax.net.ssl.keyStore=/home/user/.keystore -Djavax.net.ssl.keyStorePassword=myKeyStorePassword -Dcom.sun.management.jmxremote.ssl.need.client.auth=true -Djavax.net.ssl.trustStore=/home/user/.truststore -Djavax.net.ssl.trustStorePassword=myTrustStorePassword -Dcom.sun.management.jmxremote.registry.ssl=true -Djava.security.manager -Djava.security.policy=jmx.policy -jar lib/derbyrun.jar server start -h 0.0.0.0

trans-unit.source: When password authentication is enabled and a Java Security Manager is installed, a number of JMX-related permissions need to be granted to trusted users in the security policy used. See <xref href="radminjmxenablepolicy.dita#radminjmxenablepolicy"></xref> for details.

seg-source.mrk: When password authentication is enabled and a Java Security Manager is installed, a number of JMX-related permissions need to be granted to trusted users in the security policy used.
See <xref href="radminjmxenablepolicy.dita#radminjmxenablepolicy"></xref> for details.

target.mrk: When password authentication is enabled and a Java Security Manager is installed, a number of JMX-related permissions need to be granted to trusted users in the security policy used.
See <xref href="radminjmxenablepolicy.dita#radminjmxenablepolicy"></xref> for details.

trans-unit.source: In the example above, system properties specify the keystore containing the server's key pair, the keystore password, the truststore containing the client certificates, and the truststore password. Setting up SSL keystores and truststores is partly described in <xref href="cadminsslkeys.dita#cadminsslkeys"></xref>. Other topics in the section <xref href="cadminssl.dita#cadminssl"></xref> provide information on protecting database network traffic using SSL.

seg-source.mrk: In the example above, system properties specify the keystore containing the server's key pair, the keystore password, the truststore containing the client certificates, and the truststore password.
Setting up SSL keystores and truststores is partly described in <xref href="cadminsslkeys.dita#cadminsslkeys"></xref>.
Other topics in the section <xref href="cadminssl.dita#cadminssl"></xref> provide information on protecting database network traffic using SSL.

target.mrk: In the example above, system properties specify the keystore containing the server's key pair, the keystore password, the truststore containing the client certificates, and the truststore password.
Setting up SSL keystores and truststores is partly described in <xref href="cadminsslkeys.dita#cadminsslkeys"></xref>.
Other topics in the section <xref href="cadminssl.dita#cadminssl"></xref> provide information on protecting database network traffic using SSL.

trans-unit.source: When you configure SSL as described above, the following requirements apply:

seg-source.mrk: When you configure SSL as described above, the following requirements apply:

target.mrk: When you configure SSL as described above, the following requirements apply:

trans-unit.source: The password of the private key must be the same as the password of the keystore.

seg-source.mrk: The password of the private key must be the same as the password of the keystore.

target.mrk: The password of the private key must be the same as the password of the keystore.

trans-unit.source: If the keystore contains more than one key pair, the key pair you want to use must be listed first among all the keys in the keystore. Otherwise, you (or the clients) may see an exception with a message like the following:

seg-source.mrk: If the keystore contains more than one key pair, the key pair you want to use must be listed first among all the keys in the keystore.
Otherwise, you (or the clients) may see an exception with a message like the following:

target.mrk: If the keystore contains more than one key pair, the key pair you want to use must be listed first among all the keys in the keystore.
Otherwise, you (or the clients) may see an exception with a message like the following:

trans-unit.source: unable to find valid certification path to requested target

seg-source.mrk: unable to find valid certification path to requested target

target.mrk: unable to find valid certification path to requested target

trans-unit.source: The system property <codeph>com.sun.management.jmxremote.ssl.need.client.auth=true</codeph> specifies that clients must use SSL to authenticate themselves. This property, as well as the truststore properties, may be removed if you do not want to authenticate clients using SSL. However, there may be security risks associated with using password authentication only.

seg-source.mrk: The system property <codeph>com.sun.management.jmxremote.ssl.need.client.auth=true</codeph> specifies that clients must use SSL to authenticate themselves.
This property, as well as the truststore properties, may be removed if you do not want to authenticate clients using SSL.
However, there may be security risks associated with using password authentication only.

target.mrk: The system property <codeph>com.sun.management.jmxremote.ssl.need.client.auth=true</codeph> specifies that clients must use SSL to authenticate themselves.
This property, as well as the truststore properties, may be removed if you do not want to authenticate clients using SSL.
However, there may be security risks associated with using password authentication only.

trans-unit.source: The system property <codeph>com.sun.management.jmxremote.registry.ssl=true</codeph> was new in JDK 6 and aims at resolving security issues with the RMI registry used in relation with JMX. This property must be used in conjunction with <codeph>com.sun.management.jmxremote.ssl.need.client.auth=true</codeph> in order to fully secure the RMI registry.

seg-source.mrk: The system property <codeph>com.sun.management.jmxremote.registry.ssl=true</codeph> was new in JDK 6 and aims at resolving security issues with the RMI registry used in relation with JMX.
This property must be used in conjunction with <codeph>com.sun.management.jmxremote.ssl.need.client.auth=true</codeph> in order to fully secure the RMI registry.

target.mrk: The system property <codeph>com.sun.management.jmxremote.registry.ssl=true</codeph> was new in JDK 6 and aims at resolving security issues with the RMI registry used in relation with JMX.
This property must be used in conjunction with <codeph>com.sun.management.jmxremote.ssl.need.client.auth=true</codeph> in order to fully secure the RMI registry.

trans-unit.source: If you use a Java SE 5 JDK, clients must provide an additional entry in the environment map passed to the <codeph>JMXConnector</codeph> when enabling SSL protection of the registry:

seg-source.mrk: If you use a Java SE 5 JDK, clients must provide an additional entry in the environment map passed to the <codeph>JMXConnector</codeph> when enabling SSL protection of the registry:

target.mrk: If you use a Java SE 5 JDK, clients must provide an additional entry in the environment map passed to the <codeph>JMXConnector</codeph> when enabling SSL protection of the registry:

trans-unit.source: env.put("com.sun.jndi.rmi.factory.socket", new SslRMIClientSocketFactory());

seg-source.mrk: env.put("com.sun.jndi.rmi.factory.socket", new SslRMIClientSocketFactory());

target.mrk: env.put("com.sun.jndi.rmi.factory.socket", new SslRMIClientSocketFactory());

trans-unit.source: Clients must also specify and use proper keystores and/or truststores (the truststores must contain the server's SSL certificate).

seg-source.mrk: Clients must also specify and use proper keystores and/or truststores (the truststores must contain the server's SSL certificate).

target.mrk: Clients must also specify and use proper keystores and/or truststores (the truststores must contain the server's SSL certificate).
